Summary: The proposal introduces a multiscale neural operator (MNO) combining Fourier Neural Operators (FNOs) with graph attention mechanisms to accelerate simulations of multiscale physical systems. It aims to overcome limitations of traditional numerical methods and current ML surrogates by learning resolution-invariant representations. The method is validated through experiments on canonical PDEs, molecular dynamics, multiphysics systems, and real-world generalization tasks.
Strengths: Innovative combination of FNOs with attention mechanisms.
Detailed and comprehensive experiment plan covering multiple applications.
Strong motivation with a clear hypothesis.
Incorporation of physics-informed training and efficient deployment strategies.
Weaknesses: Limited discussion of potential technical challenges and risks.
Lacks a thorough comparison with alternative architectures or methods.
Scalability analysis lacks specific details on how challenges will be addressed.
Generalization capabilities across vastly different physical systems are not thoroughly discussed.
Questions: What are the specific technical challenges anticipated in integrating FNOs with graph attention mechanisms?
How will the proposed method handle cases where the physical system does not exhibit clear multiscale separation?
Can the authors provide more details on the adaptive mesh refinement strategy mentioned in the efficient deployment section?
What statistical methods will be used to validate the results?
Limitations: Potential challenges in integrating global and local features effectively.
Scalability may be limited by the complexity of the hybrid architecture.
Generalization to unseen boundary conditions may require extensive training data.
Computational cost of training hybrid models could be prohibitive for very large systems.
